text: President Trump has announced the
cancellation of his planned summit with
the North Korean leader Kim jong-un in a
statement the president said it was a
missed opportunity and truly a sad
moment in history he blamed what he
called Kim's tremendous anger and open
hostility in Kim's most recent statement
the summit was expected to take place in
Singapore next month when our world
affairs correspondent Jonathan Marcus
joins us now and Jonathan the White
House have issued a letter that we've
all now seen a copy of addressed to the
dear chairman well absolutely it's it's
kind of bizarre it's completely vintage
Trump it sets out very clearly that it's
very polite in its opening mr. Trump
says that he greatly appreciates Kim
jong-un's time his patience and efforts
with respect to the recent negotiations
but he says very clearly that based on
the tremendous anger and open hostility
displayed in your most recent statements
and I think that is a reference to a
statement from the Vice foreign minister
in North Korea who described the u.s.
vice president as a political dummy
talked about either meeting the
Americans in a meeting room or in a
nuclear to nuclear exchange so because
of that mr. Trump has decided to pull
the plug on these talks one has to say
they weren't going terribly well anyway
there was growing doubts about this and
then of course despite this rather
polite tone there is this explicit
threat mr. Trump says - Kim you talk
about your nuclear capabilities but ours
are so massive and powerful that I pray
to God they will never have to be used
so we're almost back now to the little
rocket man days the exchanging of taunts
around their respective nuclear programs
and it's a rather dismal the outcome I
think - what appeared to be at one stage
quite an optimistic diplomatic encounter
and yet earlier today we were reporting
that North Korea in a gesture ahead of
this summit and destroyed some test
tunnels what it had it claims to have
done this obviously one of the problems
is that it brought a set of journalists
to oversee the process from a distance
this isn't the same as a Vera
you know investigation by inspectors to
ensure what has precisely been done I
think that was always being seen as a
kind of bit of showboating and a gesture
it was a nice gesture up to a point that
we simply don't know whether North Korea
has alternative testing facilities we
don't know if for the moment the North
Koreans believe that their nuclear
program is sufficiently mature that they
don't need to carry out any further
tests in the immediate future but it is
a very curious dance that we've been
seeing over the last few weeks whole
debate about the timing of the summit
its potential location what would be
talked about I think you know there will
be many sort of seasoned diplomatic
observers who say that this was kind of
inevitable in part because it seems so
fantastic that North Korea would be
willing to give up its nuclear weapons
at anytime soon but also because this
was simply approached in completely the
wrong way
the traditional approach in diplomacy is
to sound out if there's an opportunity
then to do patient legwork perhaps for
months perhaps even years working out
you know the deliverables what can be
agreed what comes next
what process could be set in train and
then finally to announce yes you're
going to have the summit at which point
the leaders go along and sign on the
dotted lines you have the photo
opportunities for people like us and so
on this summit was approached in
entirely the opposite way they decided
they were going to have it it was all
very bizarre from the American side they
don't seem to have really considered or
what precisely they were going to expect
or demand from the North Koreans beyond
the vaguest terms and of course the key
question now is what happens next if you
think back to before the Winter Olympics
when the rhetoric between Pyongyang and
Washington what it was at its highest
there were serious experts who were
talking about a 50/50 chance of a war
between the u.s. and North Korea in the
not-too-distant future
now that was mitigated by the goodwill
surrounding the Winter Olympics you had
this period where the North Koreans
not done nuclear tests one assumes they
can't do any more now if they really
have destroyed this a testing site but
they've also seemingly suspended
ballistic missile tests for a period are
they going to review that suspension are
they going to go back to launching
ballistic missile tests and if they do
what is the American response going to
be then for the moment thank you very
much Jonathan Marcus our world affairs
correspondent let's speak to our
Washington correspondent now Gary
O'Donoghue Gary they weren't taken in
then by this gesture to blow up the
tunnels the meetings off at the moment
yeah and it's it's an extraordinary
development that's really because just a
few hours ago the president was sounding
a bit more positive certainly a lot more
positive than than this letter this
personal letter represents talking here
about anger and open hostility I mean
there is a caveat in here which says
that the meeting is off you know for the
time being effectively but there's also
a threat an extraordinary set if I may
just read you this paragraph he says
this is donald trump's kim jeong-hoon he
says you talk about your nuclear
capabilities but ours are so much more
massive and powerful that I pray God
they will never have to be used which is
a straightforward military threat if you
like a warning to the North Koreans not
to restart that program in in the way
Jonathan was just mentioning not to
start developing again that
intercontinental ballistic missile
capability and and perhaps to try and
brings them back to the table that way
but it won't go down well we know that
those sort of threats don't work well in
Pyongyang and we'll have to wait to see
what their what their reaction is but
this is a huge in a sense of you know
this was this could have been a big pot
for Impala C win for the Trump
administration to get to some sort of
meeting like that to get some sort of
dialogue and process underway that yes
there was a lot of skepticism around
about its efficacy and its potential to
actually go anywhere in the future but
just to get to that point in time would
have been something of an achievement
when as as Jonathan was saying you know
Wolf's wall was to being talked about in
very clear terms
previously this is this is a big setback
and insults don't go down particularly
well against you vice president
supposedly in Washington DC know the
don'ts I mean you know the in a sense
both sides in this have done their fair
share of that haven't they we've had
Rocketman from this side of the Pacific
and we've had all sorts of other insults
coming from the north as well so I think
in a sense that they kind of cancel
themself out a little bit but yeah it's
become it's become personalized in a way
that isn't necessarily best for for
those who would who would push the
diplomatic process forward and I think
the is a big question now for for Mike
Pompeo the new Secretary of State the
effort he's bidding he's been there
twice don't forget already in
preparation for for this summit secretly
on the first occasion not secretly on
the second occasion but he's been there
twice and as things stand it looks like
this is off for the forseeable but we
will see exactly who moves first next to
put something else on the table if they
do at all how much this is about each
side trying to wrong foot the other well
as a lot of getting work goes on don't
forget it's some it's quite hard I think
for for the US and indeed its allies to
read North Korea at times it's a very
closed society they owe the US openly
admits that it doesn't really have the
kind of level of intelligence and
information that that you would
typically be able to get in order to to
judge another side very very carefully
and very closely and very accurately so
that's been a very difficult thing but
the I think the the sort of perhaps the
speed of of the desire for for Deagan
denuclearization has crept up on the
North Koreans a little bit the
expectation of how quickly things would
happen what they would get in return we
don't know what's been said and
obviously in private sessions and they
may have been looking for a lot more
than the u.s. were prepared to give we
don't know what leverage China has
played
here whether they have met some concerns
have been raised in Beijing perhaps
about the speed at which this was
happening because they have a you know a
security concern if you like this is a
buffer North Korea as a buffer zone in
effect between China and a a substantial
American ally in Asia so there are lots
and lots of factors that could have gone
into this but I think there will be some
pressure to try and salvage something
from this because before we got to this
point of the discussion of the summit
and the discussion of negotiations like
that before that point in time we were
at a point in time where there was a
serious risk of military conflict where
the North Koreans seem to be having it
seem to be getting to a point where they
had the ballistic missile capability and
the ability to stick a nuclear weapon on
that missile and get somewhere near the
west coast of America and that was a not
just for this administration with the
one previously it was right up there in
terms of foreign policy priorities so
the meeting was the summit supposed to
have been taking place on June the 12th
in Singapore what would need to happen
certainly from the United States
perspective for it to be back on again
well I think I think for the time being
this one is off I mean there as I say
there's a small caveat in this letter
that allows for a future summit or for
something to change there are no demands
particularly in this letter so there's
no no clear indication from the
president as to what would change his
mind it would I think you have to be a
pretty substantial step but we will see
I think Mike Pompeo now the Secretary of
State will have a big job on his hands
to try and reconstruct some kind of
lines of communication to to see whether
there's any room for maneuver and
perhaps to schedule it for later on but
at the moment I think I think you'd be
you'd be you'd be wasting your money if
you bet it on this actually actually
transpiring on the June the 12th Gary
thank you very much Gary O'Donoghue
